Our lives are already fully entwined with data and a digital world we have no control over. What happens when Equifax institutes an untested AI into their credit analytics program and suddenly people who once purchased a sandwich at a specific Potbelly can no longer get a home loan?

Our lives are already fully entwined with data and a digital world we have no control over. What happens when Equifax institutes an untested AI into their credit analytics program and suddenly people who once purchased a sandwich at a specific Potbelly can no longer get a home loan?

Like, I’m not saying AI is useless. I think, eventually, it will be an important tool. But it’s just that: a tool, not an end unto itself. There’s a reason we have people design buildings and bridges, even though arguably the tech exists now to have a computer do it.

And from a code generation perspective, I don’t know when it’ll happen, but at some point there’s going to be something on the scale of Log4j or Solar Winds that will be 100% introduced by ai generated code that isn’t vetted. I just hope it’s not like…on something critical.

Like the problem with AI is that there’s a significant percentage of the time where it’s simply making shit up, but you have absolutely no idea when that is. And the more people use it, the more people will just ignore the fact that it’s simply making shit up.

One of the great misconceptions about scams is that, in the moment, they are easy to detect. 

In the moment, you’ll be distracted by work, or problems with your spouse, or something the scammers themselves invented. It’s 25% of your attention versus 100% of theirs.

Smart people fall for scams. None of you are immune, and “dunking” on a writer for sharing her story isn’t doing what you think it’s doing. I promise you, anyone (myself included!) can be tricked by the right set of circumstances.
